hints_html: What does a normal cosine graph look like? Look at what happens to some test values like \(x = 0\) or \(x = \pi\) if you plug them into the function given above instead of a normal cosine function.
hints_latex:
What does a normal cosine graph look like? Look at what happens to some
test values like $x = 0$ or $x = \pi$ if you plug them into the function
given above instead of a normal cosine function.
hints_raw: What does a normal cosine graph look like?  Look at what happens to some test values like <math>x = 0</math> or <math>x = \pi</math> if you plug them into the function given above instead of a normal cosine function.
question: 1 (a)
sols_html:
The graph of \(f(x) = \cos x\) looks like this:

The rules for shifting functions tell us that

  • Multiplying the function by 2 increases its amplitude (stretch the height of the graph) by 2,

  • subtracting by \(\pi\) on the inside of the function shifts the graph right by \(\pi\) units,

giving:

If you’ve forgotten the rules used in the first solution (or never learned them), you can also use test points. From this picture:

you have the following points, placed in a table of values:

[c]@ll@ x-value & y-value

0 & 1
\(\pi/2\) & 0
\(\pi\) & -1
\(3\pi/2\) & 0

Plugging these same x-values into \(f(x) = 2\cos (x - \pi)\) gives:

[c]@lll@ x-value & calculations & y-value

0 & \(2\cos(0 - \pi) = 2\cos(-\pi) = 2(-1)\) & -2
\(\pi/2\) & \(2\cos(\pi/2 - \pi) = 2\cos(-\pi/2) = 2(0)\) & 0
\(\pi\) & \(2\cos(\pi - \pi) = 2 \cos(0) = 2(1)\) & 2
\(3\pi/2\) & \(2\cos(3\pi/2 - \pi) = 2\cos(\pi/2) = 2(0)\) & 0

Drawing a picture based on these points, it should be clear that the graph has been shifted right by \(\pi\) and expanded vertically by 2.
sols_latex:
The graph of $f(x) = \cos x$ looks like this:

\includegraphics[width=0.5\textwidth]{../json_data/MATH110/December_2012/MER_MATH110_December_2012_Question_1a_cosine_graph.jpg}

The rules for shifting functions tell us that

\begin{itemize}
\itemsep1pt\parskip0pt\parsep0pt
\item
  Multiplying the function by 2 increases its amplitude (stretch the
  height of the graph) by 2,
\item
  subtracting by $\pi$ on the inside of the function shifts the graph
  right by $\pi$ units,
\end{itemize}

giving:

\includegraphics[width=0.5\textwidth]{../json_data/MATH110/December_2012/MER_MATH110_December_2012_Question_1a_shifting_illustration.jpg}

If you've forgotten the rules used in the first solution (or never
learned them), you can also use test points. From this picture:

\includegraphics[width=0.5\textwidth]{../json_data/MATH110/December_2012/MER_MATH110_December_2012_Question_1a_cosine_graph.jpg}

you have the following points, placed in a table of values:

\begin{longtable}[c]{@{}ll@{}}
x-value & y-value\\

0 & 1\\
$\pi/2$ & 0\\
$\pi$ & -1\\
$3\pi/2$ & 0\\
\end{longtable}

Plugging these same x-values into $f(x) = 2\cos (x - \pi)$ gives:

\begin{longtable}[c]{@{}lll@{}}
x-value & calculations & y-value\\

0 & $2\cos(0 - \pi) = 2\cos(-\pi) = 2(-1)$ & -2\\
$\pi/2$ & $2\cos(\pi/2 - \pi) = 2\cos(-\pi/2) = 2(0)$ & 0\\
$\pi$ & $2\cos(\pi - \pi) = 2 \cos(0) = 2(1)$ & 2\\
$3\pi/2$ & $2\cos(3\pi/2 - \pi) = 2\cos(\pi/2) = 2(0)$ & 0\\
\end{longtable}

Drawing a picture based on these points, it should be clear that the
graph has been shifted right by $\pi$ and expanded vertically by 2.

\includegraphics[width=0.5\textwidth]{../json_data/MATH110/December_2012/MER_MATH110_December_2012_Question_1a_shifted_cosine_graph.jpg}
sols_raw:
The graph of <math>f(x) = \cos x</math> looks like this: 

[[File:MER MATH110 December 2012 Question 1a cosine graph.jpg|400px]]

The rules for shifting functions tell us that

* Multiplying the function by 2 increases its amplitude (stretch the height of the graph) by 2, 
* subtracting by <math>\pi</math> on the inside of the function shifts the graph right by <math>\pi</math> units, 
giving: 

[[File:MER MATH110 December 2012 Question 1a shifting illustration.jpg|500px]]
If you've forgotten the rules used in the first solution (or never learned them), you can also use test points.  From this picture: 

[[File:MER MATH110 December 2012 Question 1a cosine graph.jpg|400px]]

you have the following points, placed in a table of values:

{| class="wikitable"
|-
! x-value !! y-value
|-
| 0 || 1
|-
| <math>\pi/2</math>|| 0
|-
| <math>\pi</math> || -1
|-
| <math>3\pi/2</math> || 0
|}

Plugging these same x-values into <math>f(x) = 2\cos (x - \pi)</math> gives:

{| class="wikitable"
|-
! x-value !! calculations !! y-value
|-
| 0 || <math>2\cos(0 - \pi) = 2\cos(-\pi) = 2(-1)</math> || -2 
|-
| <math>\pi/2</math> || <math>2\cos(\pi/2 - \pi) = 2\cos(-\pi/2) = 2(0)</math> || 0
|-
| <math>\pi</math> || <math>2\cos(\pi - \pi) = 2 \cos(0) = 2(1)</math> || 2
|-
| <math>3\pi/2</math> || <math>2\cos(3\pi/2 - \pi) = 2\cos(\pi/2) = 2(0) </math> || 0
|}

Drawing a picture based on these points, it should be clear that the graph has been shifted right by <math>\pi</math> and expanded vertically by 2.  

[[File:MER MATH110 December 2012 Question 1a shifted cosine graph.jpg|400px]]
statement_html:
Sketch the graph of the following function.

\(\displaystyle f(x)=2\cos(x-\pi)\)
statement_latex:
Sketch the graph of the following function.

$\displaystyle f(x)=2\cos(x-\pi)$
statement_raw:
Sketch the graph of the following function. 

<math>\displaystyle f(x)=2\cos(x-\pi)</math>
